summary: Easier - Chapter 3 - childspider - Spider-Man: Homecoming (2017) [Archive of Our Own]
body:
Easier - Chapter 3 - childspider - Spider-Man: Homecoming (2017) [Archive of Our Own]

“After civil war, the government asks all enhanced-individuals to voluntarily register or face the consequences. Peter struggles with keeping his identity secret and everyone happy, he eventually wonders if it would all be easier if he just gave up.”

Chapter 3 is up! Please give it a read and tell me what you think :)

blog.name: doctorstrangeaskblog

blog.description: Parody motivational fan made roleplay "ask blog" style for the fictional Marvel character Stephen Strange, the sassiest magician of the cosmos, NOT A DOCTOR. I DO NOT rp any innapropriate content with minors and I'll REPORT anyone I see doing so. No profit, just for fun, I'm not affiliated to Marvel or anyone, just fan made. Follow me on Twitter @drstrangefanask

summary: My personal conclusion after Infinity War about Tony and Steve.
body:
My personal conclusion after Infinity War about Tony and Steve.

Tony didn’t change even after all his movies, he found out the truth and got mental health issues because of all the shit he went through. He was always a cinnamon roll, always a good person. That’s why he suffers so much. He’s like Peter, kind to the core since the start, but who still needs to mature so they can see beyond the world’s corruption. They’re naive, upset at the world’s rotteness, struggling to make it better. Even during his party days, Tony had no idea of how the world could be cruel, he was cruel himself many times but without realizing it, maybe because his father was so harsh to him, made him believe world is pain, but still, he hadn’t met true intense pain yet.

That’s why Tony and Stephen are so different. Stephen knew all the shit he was doing, he didn’t care. He was selfish and he already knew the world, he was part of the cold world Tony and Peter try to change. Stephen, unlike Tony, he changed in essence. He reached a new level of not caring about himself anymore, 100% of his self belongs to his mission, and it’s absolutely selfless.

That’s why Stephen sounds more mature and stable than Tony in Infinity War, Tony didn’t change his own core like Stephen had to, Tony never needed to change, he needed to see the truth and mature, learn how to play among the devils of the world.

The proof is that Tony decided to stop producing weapons the exact moment he found out the truth. The same goes for Steve Rogers, he was always good, that’s why he was chosen in the first place, he also doesn’t have to change and he didn’t.

We watched pure, good characters like Tony and Steve to get more and more wounded by the cruel world they keep trying to change, and in Endgame we’ll see the closing of all those consequences.

summary: When I saw the set-up for another If This Be My Destiny moment in Spec #229, I was very unimpressed. While call-backs are cool,...
body:
When I saw the set-up for another If This Be My Destiny moment in Spec #229, I was very unimpressed. While call-backs are cool, with moments as poignant as these you can’t just do it for the laffs, the way you can do it with the Amazing Fantasy #15 cover pose of Peter web-swinging with someone under his arm, or with “you hit the jackpot” comments, it has to mean something. Also, wear causes tear, and there had been another reference in the issue where Peter has to keep the Lizard from activating a machine that might turn him back into Dr. Connors but is also a booby-trap. I don’t remember what exactly he said/was thinking that time, which cements my opinion that the reference wasn’t well used.

I thought I wouldn’t like what they did this time, either (and the fact that Peter only held out long enough for Ben to save him instead of getting out of it on his own did leave me with a sour taste on my mouth, but that might be because I’m not understanding a metaphor [besides the one about Peter actually not being capable of continuing to be Spider-Man] or/and because I’m bitter that Peter’s getting replaced). However, thay did manage to innovate enough to actually get me hooked. In moments like this, what happens isn’t what’s important, because, the fact that this was written some 30 years ago aside, I knew that Peter wouldn’t die. What’s important is the how - what he’s thinking, what he’s feeling, how he gets out of it (bleh), what impact the experiance has on him. Ultimately, I think they handled it well. Not only was it poignant, but it balanced references to the original moment (the situation, the positions, the ghostly faces of his loved ones, a mention of his “worthiness”) while still dealing with other stuff altogether. While Peter did feel he had done wrong things, this moment wasn’t about atonement, the way the first one was, but about fighting to keep living and learn from his mistakes. Getting the serum this time didn’t mean making up for his sins and the pain he’s caused (although he feels sorry for it), but about making sure he has the chance to do things right and be happy and make his family happy. In short and simple (if not simplified) terms, the first one was about the past, this one was about the future. So they were different, yet similar, and both very powerful and marked growth in the character. (Although I’m sick and tired of writers always painting Peter’s decision to stop being Spider-Man as “growing up”.)

So, yeah, I liked this parallel.

Or am I that desperate for Peter content knowing he’ll be stepping aside…?

summary: So, I know Peter's universe is (basically) our universe.
body:
So, I know Peter’s universe is (basically) our universe.

Is it safe to assume he knows about Homestuck? And if so, like the meme headcanons, do Miles and Gwen refer to it as something slightly different? Or did some other form of media get wildly popular from 2009 and onward in their universes?

summary: [when Peter is housesitting the Sanctum]Stephen: You might need to do some light housekeeping.Peter: I’ve never kept a...
body:
[when Peter is housesitting the Sanctum]

Stephen: You might need to do some light housekeeping.

Peter: I’ve never kept a lighthouse before, but I will try my best!

reblog.comment:
[when Peter is housesitting the Sanctum]

Stephen: You might need to do some light housekeeping.

Peter: I’ve never kept a lighthouse before, but I will try my best!

trail.content_raw:

Peter: I’ve never kept a lighthouse before, but I will try my best!

summary: Thing-a-Week 25: No! We do NOT Eat Cartoons! I’ve been meaning to draw Spider-Verse stuff for a VERY long time, and since I’ve...
caption:
Thing-a-Week 25: No! We do NOT Eat Cartoons!

I’ve been meaning to draw Spider-Verse stuff for a VERY long time, and since I’ve been thinking a lot about Venom lately, I figured there was no time like the present. Man. Sony really Did That huh.
